title: Did You Know May Is Melanoma Awareness Month?

content: May brings warmer weather and the promise of spring, but did you know that May is also skin cancer awareness month? While the rates of all skin cancers, including melanoma have risen dramatically over the past decades, with early detection the chances of successful treatment and better outcomes for patients are significantly higher. Unfortunately, if melanoma is not caught early, it can spread to other parts of the body and become much more difficult to treat.
Let’s Take a Closer Look at Melanoma

Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that is caused by the uncontrolled growth of pigment-producing cells in the skin called melanocytes. Melanomas typically are dark in color (dark brown or black), but not always. While it can occur in all ages, it's fairly uncommon in children. Did you know that melanoma is the No. 1 cancer affecting young adults between the ages of 25-29? In 2023, there were nearly 100,000 cases of invasive melanomas in the U.S. and 7,650 deaths.

content: UV radiation from the sun is a leading cause of melanomas, so protecting your skin from the sun is crucial in preventing melanoma. Wearing sunscreen, avoiding the sun at peak times from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., avoiding tanning beds, wearing a hat and sunglasses, and wearing UPF clothing is key in preventing skin cancers, including melanomas. Did you know that even a single episode of sunburn before the age of 18 significantly increases the risk of developing melanoma later in life? So be sure to sun protect.
Getting a mole check is also critical in detecting melanomas and skin cancers early. As dermatologists, we recommend the ABCDEs of melanomas to help patients identify suspicious lesions:
A - Asymmetry. Moles should be fairly symmetric where you can draw a line down the middle and fold onto itself; anything irregular deserves a closer look.
B - Border irregularities. You should be able to clearly draw a line around the mole and know where it starts and stops (no smudging).
C - Color variations. Moles should be fairly uniform in their coloration, even if dark; a mix of blues, reds, and whites is concerning.

sections.heading: D -
content: Diameter. Any mole greater than a pencil eraser (about 5 millimeters) gives us a pause and need for a closer look.
E - Evolving. Any mole that is new or changing deserves a closer look.

Make sure to have any suspicious moles examined by a board-certified dermatologist. A simple in-office exam may be all that is needed, or the doctor may conduct a skin biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

Fortunately, with early detection, the 5-year survival rate can be as high as 99% for melanomas confined to the skin, and patients only need a surgical excision to remove the cancer. However, as the melanoma grows deeper into the skin and other parts of the body, additional treatments may be needed, such as a lymph node biopsy or imaging studies.

Simple, sun-smart steps to protect your skin can be lifesaving! By being vigilant about changes in any moles or lesions on your skin, you can reduce your risk of developing melanomas and other skin cancers. And when caught early, the prognosis is bright!
